Denotational: Denotational semantics of untyped lambda calculus üöß

Prev • Source • Next 

module plfa.part3.Denotational where

The lambda calculus is a language about functions, that is, mappings from input to output. In computing we often think of such mappings as being carried out by a sequence of operations that transform an input into an output. But functions can also be represented as data. For example, one can tabulate a function, that is, create a table where each row has two entries, an input and the corresponding output for the function. Function application is then the process of looking up the row for a given input and reading off the output.

We shall create a semantics for the untyped lambda calculus based on this idea of functions-as-tables. However, there are two difficulties that arise. First, functions often have an infinite domain, so it would seem that we would need infinitely long tables to represent functions. Second, in the lambda calculus, functions can be applied to functions. They can even be applied to themselves! So it would seem that the tables would contain cycles. One might start to worry that advanced techniques are necessary to address these issues, but fortunately this is not the case!

The first problem, of functions with infinite domains, is solved by observing that in the execution of a terminating program, each lambda abstraction will only be applied to a finite number of distinct arguments. (We come back later to discuss diverging programs.) This observation is another way of looking at Dana Scott‚Äôs insight that only continuous functions are needed to model the lambda calculus.

The second problem, that of self-application, is solved by relaxing the way in which we lookup an argument in a function‚Äôs table. Naively, one would look in the table for a row in which the input entry exactly matches the argument. In the case of self-application, this would require the table to contain a copy of itself. Impossible! (At least, it is impossible if we want to build tables using inductive data type definitions, which indeed we do.) Instead it is sufficient to find an input such that every row of the input appears as a row of the argument (that is, the input is a subset of the argument). In the case of self-application, the table only needs to contain a smaller copy of itself, which is fine.

With these two observations in hand, it is straightforward to write down a denotational semantics of the lambda calculus.

Imports

open import Agda.Primitive using (lzero; lsuc)
open import Data.Empty using (‚ä•-elim)
open import Data.Product using (_√ó_; Œ£; Œ£-syntax; ‚àÉ; ‚àÉ-syntax; proj‚ÇÅ; proj‚ÇÇ)
  renaming (_,_ to ‚ü®_,_‚ü©)
open import Data.Sum
open import Relation.Binary.PropositionalEquality
  using (_‚â°_; _‚â¢_; refl; sym; cong; cong‚ÇÇ; cong-app)
open import Relation.Nullary using (¬¨_)
open import Relation.Nullary.Negation using (contradiction)
open import Function using (_‚àò_)
open import plfa.part2.Untyped
  using (Context; ‚òÖ; _‚àã_; ‚àÖ; _,_; Z; S_; _‚ä¢_; `_; _¬∑_; ∆õ_;
         #_; two·∂ú; ext; rename; exts; subst; subst-zero; _[_])
open import plfa.part2.Substitution using (Rename; extensionality; rename-id)

Values

The Value data type represents a finite portion of a function. We think of a value as a finite set of pairs that represent input-output mappings. The Value data type represents the set as a binary tree whose internal nodes are the union operator and whose leaves represent either a single mapping or the empty set.

  • The ‚ä• value provides no information about the computation.

  • A value of the form v ‚Ü¶ w is a single input-output mapping, from input v to output w.

  • A value of the form v ‚äî w is a function that maps inputs to outputs according to both v and w. Think of it as taking the union of the two sets.

infixr 7 _‚Ü¶_
infixl 5 _‚äî_

data Value : Set where
  ‚ä• : Value
  _‚Ü¶_ : Value ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Value
  _‚äî_ : Value ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Value

The ‚äë relation adapts the familiar notion of subset to the Value data type. This relation plays the key role in enabling self-application. There are two rules that are specific to functions, ‚äë-fun and ‚äë-dist, which we discuss below.

infix 4 _‚äë_

data _‚äë_ : Value ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Set where

  ‚äë-bot : ‚àÄ {v} ‚Üí ‚ä• ‚äë v

  ‚äë-conj-L : ‚àÄ {u v w}
    ‚Üí v ‚äë u
    ‚Üí w ‚äë u
      -----------
    ‚Üí (v ‚äî w) ‚äë u

  ‚äë-conj-R1 : ‚àÄ {u v w}
    ‚Üí u ‚äë v
      -----------
    ‚Üí u ‚äë (v ‚äî w)

  ‚äë-conj-R2 : ‚àÄ {u v w}
    ‚Üí u ‚äë w
      -----------
    ‚Üí u ‚äë (v ‚äî w)

  ‚äë-trans : ‚àÄ {u v w}
    ‚Üí u ‚äë v
    ‚Üí v ‚äë w
      -----
    ‚Üí u ‚äë w

  ‚äë-fun : ‚àÄ {v w v‚Ä≤ w‚Ä≤}
    ‚Üí v‚Ä≤ ‚äë v
    ‚Üí w ‚äë w‚Ä≤
      -------------------
    ‚Üí (v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚äë (v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤)

  ‚äë-dist : ‚àÄ{v w w‚Ä≤}
      ---------------------------------
    ‚Üí v ‚Ü¶ (w ‚äî w‚Ä≤) ‚äë (v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚äî (v ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤)

The first five rules are straightforward. The rule ‚äë-fun captures when it is OK to match a higher-order argument v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ to a table entry whose input is v ‚Ü¶ w. Considering a call to the higher-order argument. It is OK to pass a larger argument than expected, so v can be larger than v‚Ä≤. Also, it is OK to disregard some of the output, so w can be smaller than w‚Ä≤. The rule ‚äë-dist says that if you have two entries for the same input, then you can combine them into a single entry and joins the two outputs.

The ‚äë relation is reflexive.

‚äë-refl : ‚àÄ {v} ‚Üí v ‚äë v
‚äë-refl {‚ä•} = ‚äë-bot
‚äë-refl {v ‚Ü¶ v‚Ä≤} = ‚äë-fun ‚äë-refl ‚äë-refl
‚äë-refl {v‚ÇÅ ‚äî v‚ÇÇ} = ‚äë-conj-L (‚äë-conj-R1 ‚äë-refl) (‚äë-conj-R2 ‚äë-refl)

The ‚äî operation is monotonic with respect to ‚äë, that is, given two larger values it produces a larger value.

‚äî‚äë‚äî : ‚àÄ {v w v‚Ä≤ w‚Ä≤}
  ‚Üí v ‚äë v‚Ä≤  ‚Üí  w ‚äë w‚Ä≤
    -----------------------
  ‚Üí (v ‚äî w) ‚äë (v‚Ä≤ ‚äî w‚Ä≤)
‚äî‚äë‚äî d‚ÇÅ d‚ÇÇ = ‚äë-conj-L (‚äë-conj-R1 d‚ÇÅ) (‚äë-conj-R2 d‚ÇÇ)

The ‚äë-dist rule can be used to combine two entries even when the input values are not identical. One can first combine the two inputs using ‚äî and then apply the ‚äë-dist rule to obtain the following property.

‚äî‚Ü¶‚äî-dist : ‚àÄ{v v‚Ä≤ w w‚Ä≤ : Value}
  ‚Üí (v ‚äî v‚Ä≤) ‚Ü¶ (w ‚äî w‚Ä≤) ‚äë (v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚äî (v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤)
‚äî‚Ü¶‚äî-dist = ‚äë-trans ‚äë-dist (‚äî‚äë‚äî (‚äë-fun (‚äë-conj-R1 ‚äë-refl) ‚äë-refl)
                            (‚äë-fun (‚äë-conj-R2 ‚äë-refl) ‚äë-refl))

If the join u ‚äî v is less than another value w, then both u and v are less than w.

‚äî‚äë-invL : ‚àÄ{u v w : Value}
  ‚Üí u ‚äî v ‚äë w
    ---------
  ‚Üí u ‚äë w
‚äî‚äë-invL (‚äë-conj-L lt1 lt2) = lt1
‚äî‚äë-invL (‚äë-conj-R1 lt) = ‚äë-conj-R1 (‚äî‚äë-invL lt)
‚äî‚äë-invL (‚äë-conj-R2 lt) = ‚äë-conj-R2 (‚äî‚äë-invL lt)
‚äî‚äë-invL (‚äë-trans lt1 lt2) = ‚äë-trans (‚äî‚äë-invL lt1) lt2

‚äî‚äë-invR : ‚àÄ{u v w : Value}
  ‚Üí u ‚äî v ‚äë w
    ---------
  ‚Üí v ‚äë w
‚äî‚äë-invR (‚äë-conj-L lt1 lt2) = lt2
‚äî‚äë-invR (‚äë-conj-R1 lt) = ‚äë-conj-R1 (‚äî‚äë-invR lt)
‚äî‚äë-invR (‚äë-conj-R2 lt) = ‚äë-conj-R2 (‚äî‚äë-invR lt)
‚äî‚äë-invR (‚äë-trans lt1 lt2) = ‚äë-trans (‚äî‚äë-invR lt1) lt2

Environments

An environment gives meaning to the free variables in a term by mapping variables to values.

Env : Context ‚Üí Set
Env Œì = ‚àÄ (x : Œì ‚àã ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Value

We have the empty environment, and we can extend an environment.

`‚àÖ : Env ‚àÖ
`‚àÖ ()

infixl 5 _`,_

_`,_ : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí Env Œì ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Env (Œì , ‚òÖ)
(Œ≥ `, v) Z = v
(Œ≥ `, v) (S x) = Œ≥ x

We can recover the previous environment from an extended environment, and the last value. Putting them together again takes us back to where we started.

init : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí Env (Œì , ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Env Œì
init Œ≥ x = Œ≥ (S x)

last : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí Env (Œì , ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Value
last Œ≥ = Œ≥ Z

init-last : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí (Œ≥ : Env (Œì , ‚òÖ)) ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚â° (init Œ≥ `, last Œ≥)
init-last {Œì} Œ≥ = extensionality lemma
  where lemma : ‚àÄ (x : Œì , ‚òÖ ‚àã ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Œ≥ x ‚â° (init Œ≥ `, last Œ≥) x
        lemma Z      =  refl
        lemma (S x)  =  refl

We extend the ‚äë relation point-wise to environments with the following definition.

_`‚äë_ : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí Env Œì ‚Üí Env Œì ‚Üí Set
_`‚äë_ {Œì} Œ≥ Œ¥ = ‚àÄ (x : Œì ‚àã ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Œ≥ x ‚äë Œ¥ x

We define a bottom environment and a join operator on environments, which takes the point-wise join of their values.

`‚ä• : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí Env Œì
`‚ä• x = ‚ä•

_`‚äî_ : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí Env Œì ‚Üí Env Œì ‚Üí Env Œì
(Œ≥ `‚äî Œ¥) x = Œ≥ x ‚äî Œ¥ x

The ‚äë-refl, ‚äë-conj-R1, and ‚äë-conj-R2 rules lift to environments. So the join of two environments Œ≥ and Œ¥ is greater than the first environment Œ≥ or the second environment Œ¥.

`‚äë-refl : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} ‚Üí Œ≥ `‚äë Œ≥
`‚äë-refl {Œì} {Œ≥} x = ‚äë-refl {Œ≥ x}

‚äë-env-conj-R1 : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí (Œ≥ : Env Œì) ‚Üí (Œ¥ : Env Œì) ‚Üí Œ≥ `‚äë (Œ≥ `‚äî Œ¥)
‚äë-env-conj-R1 Œ≥ Œ¥ x = ‚äë-conj-R1 ‚äë-refl

‚äë-env-conj-R2 : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí (Œ≥ : Env Œì) ‚Üí (Œ¥ : Env Œì) ‚Üí Œ¥ `‚äë (Œ≥ `‚äî Œ¥)
‚äë-env-conj-R2 Œ≥ Œ¥ x = ‚äë-conj-R2 ‚äë-refl

Denotational Semantics

We define the semantics with a judgment of the form œÅ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v, where œÅ is the environment, M the program, and v is a result value. For readers familiar with big-step semantics, this notation will feel quite natural, but don‚Äôt let the similarity fool you. There are subtle but important differences! So here is the definition of the semantics, which we discuss in detail in the following paragraphs.

infix 3 _‚ä¢_‚Üì_

data _‚ä¢_‚Üì_ : ‚àÄ{Œì} ‚Üí Env Œì ‚Üí (Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Set where

  var : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {x}
      ---------------
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ (` x) ‚Üì Œ≥ x

  ‚Ü¶-elim : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {L M v w}
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ L ‚Üì (v ‚Ü¶ w)
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
      ---------------
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ (L ¬∑ M) ‚Üì w

  ‚Ü¶-intro : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {N v w}
    ‚Üí Œ≥ `, v ‚ä¢ N ‚Üì w
      -------------------
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ (∆õ N) ‚Üì (v ‚Ü¶ w)

  ‚ä•-intro : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {M}
      ---------
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì ‚ä•

  ‚äî-intro : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {M v w}
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì w
      ---------------
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì (v ‚äî w)

  sub : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {M v w}
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
    ‚Üí w ‚äë v
      ---------
    ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì w

Consider the rule for lambda abstractions, ‚Ü¶-intro. It says that a lambda abstraction results in a single-entry table that maps the input v to the output w, provided that evaluating the body in an environment with v bound to its parameter produces the output w. As a simple example of this rule, we can see that the identity function maps ‚ä• to ‚ä• and also that it maps ‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä• to ‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•.

id : ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ
id = ∆õ # 0

denot-id1 : ‚àÄ {Œ≥} ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ id ‚Üì ‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•
denot-id1 = ‚Ü¶-intro var

denot-id2 : ‚àÄ {Œ≥} ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ id ‚Üì (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•) ‚Ü¶ (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•)
denot-id2 = ‚Ü¶-intro var

Of course, we will need tables with many rows to capture the meaning of lambda abstractions. These can be constructed using the ‚äî-intro rule. If term M (typically a lambda abstraction) can produce both tables v and w, then it produces the combined table v ‚äî w. One can take an operational view of the rules ‚Ü¶-intro and ‚äî-intro by imagining that when an interpreter first comes to a lambda abstraction, it pre-evaluates the function on a bunch of randomly chosen arguments, using many instances of the rule ‚Ü¶-intro, and then joins them into a big table using many instances of the rule ‚äî-intro. In the following we show that the identity function produces a table containing both of the previous results, ‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä• and (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•) ‚Ü¶ (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•).

denot-id3 : `‚àÖ ‚ä¢ id ‚Üì (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•) ‚äî (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•) ‚Ü¶ (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•)
denot-id3 = ‚äî-intro denot-id1 denot-id2

We most often think of the judgment Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v as taking the environment Œ≥ and term M as input, producing the result v. However, it is worth emphasizing that the semantics is a relation. The above results for the identity function show that the same environment and term can be mapped to different results. However, the results for a given Œ≥ and M are not too different, they are all finite approximations of the same function. Perhaps a better way of thinking about the judgment Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v is that the Œ≥, M, and v are all inputs and the semantics either confirms or denies whether v is an accurate partial description of the result of M in environment Œ≥.

Next we consider the meaning of function application as given by the ‚Ü¶-elim rule. In the premise of the rule we have that L maps v to w. So if M produces v, then the application of L to M produces w.

As an example of function application and the ‚Ü¶-elim rule, we apply the identity function to itself. Indeed, we have both that ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ id ‚Üì (u ‚Ü¶ u) ‚Ü¶ (u ‚Ü¶ u) and also ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ id ‚Üì (u ‚Ü¶ u), so we can apply the rule ‚Ü¶-elim.

id-app-id : ‚àÄ {u : Value} ‚Üí `‚àÖ ‚ä¢ id ¬∑ id ‚Üì (u ‚Ü¶ u)
id-app-id {u} = ‚Ü¶-elim (‚Ü¶-intro var) (‚Ü¶-intro var)

Next we revisit the Church numeral two. This function has two parameters: a function and an arbitrary value u, and it applies the function twice. So the function must map u to some value, which we‚Äôll name v. Then for the second application, it must map v to some value. Let‚Äôs name it w. So the parameter‚Äôs table must contain two entries, both u ‚Ü¶ v and v ‚Ü¶ w. For each application of the table, we extract the appropriate entry from it using the sub rule. In particular, we use the ‚äë-conj-R1 and ‚äë-conj-R2 to select u ‚Ü¶ v and v ‚Ü¶ w, respectively, from the table u ‚Ü¶ v ‚äî v ‚Ü¶ w. So the meaning of two·∂ú is that it takes this table and parameter u, and it returns w. Indeed we derive this as follows.

denot-two·∂ú : ‚àÄ{u v w : Value} ‚Üí `‚àÖ ‚ä¢ two·∂ú ‚Üì ((u ‚Ü¶ v ‚äî v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚Ü¶ (u ‚Ü¶ w))
denot-two·∂ú {u}{v}{w} =
  ‚Ü¶-intro (‚Ü¶-intro (‚Ü¶-elim (sub var lt1) (‚Ü¶-elim (sub var lt2) var)))
  where lt1 : v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äë u ‚Ü¶ v ‚äî v ‚Ü¶ w
        lt1 = ‚äë-conj-R2 (‚äë-fun ‚äë-refl ‚äë-refl)

        lt2 : u ‚Ü¶ v ‚äë u ‚Ü¶ v ‚äî v ‚Ü¶ w
        lt2 = (‚äë-conj-R1 (‚äë-fun ‚äë-refl ‚äë-refl))

Next we have a classic example of self application: Œî = Œªx. (x x). The input value for x needs to be a table, and it needs to have an entry that maps a smaller version of itself, call it v, to some value w. So the input value looks like v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äî v. Of course, then the output of Œî is w. The derivation is given below. The first occurrences of x evaluates to v ‚Ü¶ w, the second occurrence of x evaluates to v, and then the result of the application is w.

Œî : ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ
Œî = (∆õ (# 0) ¬∑ (# 0))

denot-Œî : ‚àÄ {v w} ‚Üí `‚àÖ ‚ä¢ Œî ‚Üì ((v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äî v) ‚Ü¶ w)
denot-Œî = ‚Ü¶-intro (‚Ü¶-elim (sub var (‚äë-conj-R1 ‚äë-refl))
                          (sub var (‚äë-conj-R2 ‚äë-refl)))

One might worry whether this semantics can deal with diverging programs. The ‚ä• value and the ‚ä•-intro rule provide a way to handle them. (The ‚ä•-intro rule is also what enables Œ≤ reduction on non-terminating arguments.) The classic Œ© program is a particularly simple program that diverges. It applies Œî to itself. The semantics assigns to Œ© the meaning ‚ä•. There are several ways to derive this, we shall start with one that makes use of the ‚äî-intro rule. First, denot-Œî tells us that Œî evaluates to ((‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•) ‚äî ‚ä•) ‚Ü¶ ‚ä• (choose v‚ÇÅ = v‚ÇÇ = ‚ä•). Next, Œî also evaluates to ‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä• by use of ‚Ü¶-intro and ‚ä•-intro and to ‚ä• by ‚ä•-intro. As we saw previously, whenever we can show that a program evaluates to two values, we can apply ‚äî-intro to join them together, so Œî evaluates to (‚ä• ‚Ü¶ ‚ä•) ‚äî ‚ä•. This matches the input of the first occurrence of Œî, so we can conclude that the result of the application is ‚ä•.

Œ© : ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ
Œ© = Œî ¬∑ Œî

denot-Œ© : `‚àÖ ‚ä¢ Œ© ‚Üì ‚ä•
denot-Œ© = ‚Ü¶-elim denot-Œî (‚äî-intro (‚Ü¶-intro ‚ä•-intro) ‚ä•-intro)

A shorter derivation of the same result is by just one use of the ‚ä•-intro rule.

denot-Œ©' : `‚àÖ ‚ä¢ Œ© ‚Üì ‚ä•
denot-Œ©' = ‚ä•-intro

Just because one can derive ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì ‚ä• for some closed term M doesn‚Äôt mean that M necessarily diverges. There may be other derivations that conclude with M producing some more informative value. However, if the only thing that a term evaluates to is ‚ä•, then it indeed diverges.

An attentive reader may have noticed a disconnect earlier in the way we planned to solve the self-application problem and the actual ‚Ü¶-elim rule for application. We said at the beginning that we would relax the notion of table lookup, allowing an argument to match an input entry if the argument is equal or greater than the input entry. Instead, the ‚Ü¶-elim rule seems to require an exact match. However, because of the sub rule, application really does allow larger arguments.

‚Ü¶-elim2 : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ v‚ÇÅ v‚ÇÇ v‚ÇÉ}
  ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M‚ÇÅ ‚Üì (v‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ v‚ÇÉ)
  ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M‚ÇÇ ‚Üì v‚ÇÇ
  ‚Üí v‚ÇÅ ‚äë v‚ÇÇ
    ------------------
  ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ (M‚ÇÅ ¬∑ M‚ÇÇ) ‚Üì v‚ÇÉ
‚Ü¶-elim2 d‚ÇÅ d‚ÇÇ lt = ‚Ü¶-elim d‚ÇÅ (sub d‚ÇÇ lt)

Exercise denot-plus·∂ú (practice)

What is a denotation for plus·∂ú? That is, find a value v (other than ‚ä•) such that ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ plus·∂ú ‚Üì v. Also, give the proof of ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ plus·∂ú ‚Üì v for your choice of v.

Denotations and denotational equality

Next we define a notion of denotational equality based on the above semantics. Its statement makes use of an if-and-only-if, which we define as follows.

_iff_ : Set ‚Üí Set ‚Üí Set
P iff Q = (P ‚Üí Q) √ó (Q ‚Üí P)

Another way to view the denotational semantics is as a function that maps a term to a relation from environments to values. That is, the denotation of a term is a relation from environments to values.

Denotation : Context ‚Üí Set‚ÇÅ
Denotation Œì = (Env Œì ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Set)

The following function ‚Ñ∞ gives this alternative view of the semantics, which really just amounts to changing the order of the parameters.

‚Ñ∞ : ‚àÄ{Œì} ‚Üí (M : Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ) ‚Üí Denotation Œì
‚Ñ∞ M = Œª Œ≥ v ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v

In general, two denotations are equal when they produce the same values in the same environment.

infix 3 _‚âÉ_

_‚âÉ_ : ‚àÄ {Œì} ‚Üí (Denotation Œì) ‚Üí (Denotation Œì) ‚Üí Set
(_‚âÉ_ {Œì} D‚ÇÅ D‚ÇÇ) = (Œ≥ : Env Œì) ‚Üí (v : Value) ‚Üí D‚ÇÅ Œ≥ v iff D‚ÇÇ Œ≥ v

Denotational equality is an equivalence relation.

‚âÉ-refl : ‚àÄ {Œì : Context} ‚Üí {M : Denotation Œì}
  ‚Üí M ‚âÉ M
‚âÉ-refl Œ≥ v = ‚ü® (Œª x ‚Üí x) , (Œª x ‚Üí x) ‚ü©

‚âÉ-sym : ‚àÄ {Œì : Context} ‚Üí {M N : Denotation Œì}
  ‚Üí M ‚âÉ N
    -----
  ‚Üí N ‚âÉ M
‚âÉ-sym eq Œ≥ v = ‚ü® (proj‚ÇÇ (eq Œ≥ v)) , (proj‚ÇÅ (eq Œ≥ v)) ‚ü©

‚âÉ-trans : ‚àÄ {Œì : Context} ‚Üí {M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ M‚ÇÉ : Denotation Œì}
  ‚Üí M‚ÇÅ ‚âÉ M‚ÇÇ
  ‚Üí M‚ÇÇ ‚âÉ M‚ÇÉ
    -------
  ‚Üí M‚ÇÅ ‚âÉ M‚ÇÉ
‚âÉ-trans eq1 eq2 Œ≥ v = ‚ü® (Œª z ‚Üí proj‚ÇÅ (eq2 Œ≥ v) (proj‚ÇÅ (eq1 Œ≥ v) z)) ,
                        (Œª z ‚Üí proj‚ÇÇ (eq1 Œ≥ v) (proj‚ÇÇ (eq2 Œ≥ v) z)) ‚ü©

Two terms M and N are denotational equal when their denotations are equal, that is, ‚Ñ∞ M ‚âÉ ‚Ñ∞ N.

The following submodule introduces equational reasoning for the ‚âÉ relation.

module ‚âÉ-Reasoning {Œì : Context} where

  infix  1 start_
  infixr 2 _‚âÉ‚ü®‚ü©_ _‚âÉ‚ü®_‚ü©_
  infix  3 _‚òê

  start_ : ‚àÄ {x y : Denotation Œì}
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ y
      -----
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ y
  start x‚âÉy  =  x‚âÉy

  _‚âÉ‚ü®_‚ü©_ : ‚àÄ (x : Denotation Œì) {y z : Denotation Œì}
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ y
    ‚Üí y ‚âÉ z
      -----
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ z
  (x ‚âÉ‚ü® x‚âÉy ‚ü© y‚âÉz) =  ‚âÉ-trans x‚âÉy y‚âÉz

  _‚âÉ‚ü®‚ü©_ : ‚àÄ (x : Denotation Œì) {y : Denotation Œì}
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ y
      -----
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ y
  x ‚âÉ‚ü®‚ü© x‚âÉy  =  x‚âÉy

  _‚òê : ‚àÄ (x : Denotation Œì)
      -----
    ‚Üí x ‚âÉ x
  (x ‚òê)  =  ‚âÉ-refl

Road map for the following chapters

The subsequent chapters prove that the denotational semantics has several desirable properties. First, we prove that the semantics is compositional, i.e., that the denotation of a term is a function of the denotations of its subterms. To do this we shall prove equations of the following shape.

‚Ñ∞ (` x) ‚âÉ ...
‚Ñ∞ (∆õ M) ‚âÉ ... ‚Ñ∞ M ...
‚Ñ∞ (M ¬∑ N) ‚âÉ ... ‚Ñ∞ M ... ‚Ñ∞ N ...

The compositionality property is not trivial because the semantics we have defined includes three rules that are not syntax directed: ‚ä•-intro, ‚äî-intro, and sub. The above equations suggest that the dentoational semantics can be defined as a recursive function, and indeed, we give such a definition and prove that it is equivalent to ‚Ñ∞.

Next we investigate whether the denotational semantics and the reduction semantics are equivalent. Recall that the job of a language semantics is to describe the observable behavior of a given program M. For the lambda calculus there are several choices that one can make, but they usually boil down to a single bit of information:

  • divergence: the program M executes forever.
  • termination: the program M halts.

We can characterize divergence and termination in terms of reduction.

  • divergence: ¬¨ (M ‚Äî‚Ü† ∆õ N) for any term N.
  • termination: M ‚Äî‚Ü† ∆õ N for some term N.

We can also characterize divergence and termination using denotations.

  • divergence: ¬¨ (‚àÖ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v ‚Ü¶ w) for any v and w.
  • termination: ‚àÖ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v ‚Ü¶ w for some v and w.

Alternatively, we can use the denotation function ‚Ñ∞.

  • divergence: ¬¨ (‚Ñ∞ M ‚âÉ ‚Ñ∞ (∆õ N)) for any term N.
  • termination: ‚Ñ∞ M ‚âÉ ‚Ñ∞ (∆õ N) for some term N.

So the question is whether the reduction semantics and denotational semantics are equivalent.

(‚àÉ N. M ‚Äî‚Ü† ∆õ N)  iff  (‚àÉ N. ‚Ñ∞ M ‚âÉ ‚Ñ∞ (∆õ N))

We address each direction of the equivalence in the second and third chapters. In the second chapter we prove that reduction to a lambda abstraction implies denotational equality to a lambda abstraction. This property is called the soundness in the literature.

M ‚Äî‚Ü† ∆õ N  implies  ‚Ñ∞ M ‚âÉ ‚Ñ∞ (∆õ N)

In the third chapter we prove that denotational equality to a lambda abstraction implies reduction to a lambda abstraction. This property is called adequacy in the literature.

‚Ñ∞ M ‚âÉ ‚Ñ∞ (∆õ N)  implies M ‚Äî‚Ü† ∆õ N‚Ä≤ for some N‚Ä≤

The fourth chapter applies the results of the three preceeding chapters (compositionality, soundness, and adequacy) to prove that denotational equality implies a property called contextual equivalence. This property is important because it justifies the use of denotational equality in proving the correctness of program transformations such as performance optimizations.

The proofs of all of these properties rely on some basic results about the denotational semantics, which we establish in the rest of this chapter. We start with some lemmas about renaming, which are quite similar to the renaming lemmas that we have seen in previous chapters. We conclude with a proof of an important inversion lemma for the less-than relation regarding function values.

Renaming preserves denotations

We shall prove that renaming variables, and changing the environment accordingly, preserves the meaning of a term. We generalize the renaming lemma to allow the values in the new environment to be the same or larger than the original values. This generalization is useful in proving that reduction implies denotational equality.

As before, we need an extension lemma to handle the case where we proceed underneath a lambda abstraction. Suppose that œÅ is a renaming that maps variables in Œ≥ into variables with equal or larger values in Œ¥. This lemmas says that extending the renaming producing a renaming ext r that maps Œ≥ , v to Œ¥ , v.

ext-‚äë : ‚àÄ {Œì Œî v} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {Œ¥ : Env Œî}
  ‚Üí (œÅ : Rename Œì Œî)
  ‚Üí Œ≥ `‚äë (Œ¥ ‚àò œÅ)
    ------------------------------
  ‚Üí (Œ≥ `, v) `‚äë ((Œ¥ `, v) ‚àò ext œÅ)
ext-‚äë œÅ lt Z = ‚äë-refl
ext-‚äë œÅ lt (S n‚Ä≤) = lt n‚Ä≤

We proceed by cases on the de Bruijn index n.

  • If it is Z, then we just need to show that v ‚â° v, which we have by refl.

  • If it is S n‚Ä≤, then the goal simplifies to Œ≥ n‚Ä≤ ‚â° Œ¥ (œÅ n‚Ä≤), which is an instance of the premise.

Now for the renaming lemma. Suppose we have a renaming that maps variables in Œ≥ into variables with the same values in Œ¥. If M results in v when evaluated in environment Œ≥, then applying the renaming to M produces a program that results in the same value v when evaluated in Œ¥.

rename-pres : ‚àÄ {Œì Œî v} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {Œ¥ : Env Œî} {M : Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}
  ‚Üí (œÅ : Rename Œì Œî)
  ‚Üí Œ≥ `‚äë (Œ¥ ‚àò œÅ)
  ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
    ---------------------
  ‚Üí Œ¥ ‚ä¢ (rename œÅ M) ‚Üì v
rename-pres œÅ lt (var {x = x}) = sub var (lt x)
rename-pres œÅ lt (‚Ü¶-elim d d‚ÇÅ) =
   ‚Ü¶-elim (rename-pres œÅ lt d) (rename-pres œÅ lt d‚ÇÅ)
rename-pres œÅ lt (‚Ü¶-intro d) =
   ‚Ü¶-intro (rename-pres (ext œÅ) (ext-‚äë œÅ lt) d)
rename-pres œÅ lt ‚ä•-intro = ‚ä•-intro
rename-pres œÅ lt (‚äî-intro d d‚ÇÅ) =
   ‚äî-intro (rename-pres œÅ lt d) (rename-pres œÅ lt d‚ÇÅ)
rename-pres œÅ lt (sub d lt‚Ä≤) =
   sub (rename-pres œÅ lt d) lt‚Ä≤

The proof is by induction on the semantics of M. As you can see, all of the cases are trivial except the cases for variables and lambda.

  • For a variable x, we make use of the premise to show that Œ≥ x ‚â° Œ¥ (œÅ x).

  • For a lambda abstraction, the induction hypothesis requires us to extend the renaming. We do so, and use the ext-‚äë lemma to show that the extended renaming maps variables to ones with equivalent values.

Identity renamings and environment strengthening

We shall need a corollary of the renaming lemma that says that if M results in v, then we can replace a value in the environment with a larger one (a stronger one), and M still results in v. In particular, if Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v and Œ≥ ‚äë Œ¥, then Œ¥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v. What does this have to do with renaming? It‚Äôs renaming with the identity function. So we apply the renaming lemma with the identity renaming, which gives us Œ¥ ‚ä¢ rename (Œª {A} x ‚Üí x) M ‚Üì v, and then we apply the rename-id lemma to obtain Œ¥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v.

‚äë-env : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {Œ¥ : Env Œì} {M v}
  ‚Üí Œ≥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
  ‚Üí Œ≥ `‚äë Œ¥
    ----------
  ‚Üí Œ¥ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
‚äë-env{Œì}{Œ≥}{Œ¥}{M}{v} d lt
      with rename-pres{Œì}{Œì}{v}{Œ≥}{Œ¥}{M} (Œª {A} x ‚Üí x) lt d
... | d‚Ä≤ rewrite rename-id {Œì}{‚òÖ}{M} =
      d‚Ä≤

In the proof that substitution reflects denotations, in the case for lambda abstraction, we use a minor variation of ‚äë-env, in which just the last element of the environment gets larger.

up-env : ‚àÄ {Œì} {Œ≥ : Env Œì} {M v u‚ÇÅ u‚ÇÇ}
  ‚Üí (Œ≥ `, u‚ÇÅ) ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
  ‚Üí u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ
    -----------------
  ‚Üí (Œ≥ `, u‚ÇÇ) ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v
up-env d lt = ‚äë-env d (ext-le lt)
  where
  ext-le : ‚àÄ {Œ≥ u‚ÇÅ u‚ÇÇ} ‚Üí u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ ‚Üí (Œ≥ `, u‚ÇÅ) `‚äë (Œ≥ `, u‚ÇÇ)
  ext-le lt Z = lt
  ext-le lt (S n) = ‚äë-refl

Inversion of the less-than relation for functions

What can we deduce from knowing that a function v ‚Ü¶ w is less than some value u? What can we deduce about u? The answer to this question is called the inversion property of less-than for functions. This question is not easy to answer because of the ‚äë-dist rule, which relates a function on the left to a pair of functions on the right. So u may include several functions that, as a group, relate to v ‚Ü¶ w. Furthermore, because of the rules ‚äë-conj-R1 and ‚äë-conj-R2, there may be other values inside u, such as ‚ä•, that have nothing to do with v ‚Ü¶ w. But in general, we can deduce that u includes a collection of functions where the join of their domains is less than v and the join of their codomains is greater than w.

To precisely state and prove this inversion property, we need to define what it means for a value to include a collection of values. We also need to define how to compute the join of their domains and codomains.

Value membership and inclusion

Recall that we think of a value as a set of entries with the join operator v ‚äî w acting like set union. The function value v ‚Ü¶ w and bottom value ‚ä• constitute the two kinds of elements of the set. (In other contexts one can instead think of ‚ä• as the empty set, but here we must think of it as an element.) We write u ‚àà v to say that u is an element of v, as defined below.

infix 5 _‚àà_

_‚àà_ : Value ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Set
u ‚àà ‚ä• = u ‚â° ‚ä•
u ‚àà v ‚Ü¶ w = u ‚â° v ‚Ü¶ w
u ‚àà (v ‚äî w) = u ‚àà v ‚äé u ‚àà w

So we can represent a collection of values simply as a value. We write v ‚äÜ w to say that all the elements of v are also in w.

infix 5 _‚äÜ_

_‚äÜ_ : Value ‚Üí Value ‚Üí Set
v ‚äÜ w = ‚àÄ{u} ‚Üí u ‚àà v ‚Üí u ‚àà w

The notions of membership and inclusion for values are closely related to the less-than relation. They are narrower relations in that they imply the less-than relation but not the other way around.

‚àà‚Üí‚äë : ‚àÄ{u v : Value}
    ‚Üí u ‚àà v
      -----
    ‚Üí u ‚äë v
‚àà‚Üí‚äë {.‚ä•} {‚ä•} refl = ‚äë-bot
‚àà‚Üí‚äë {v ‚Ü¶ w} {v ‚Ü¶ w} refl = ‚äë-refl
‚àà‚Üí‚äë {u} {v ‚äî w} (inj‚ÇÅ x) = ‚äë-conj-R1 (‚àà‚Üí‚äë x)
‚àà‚Üí‚äë {u} {v ‚äî w} (inj‚ÇÇ y) = ‚äë-conj-R2 (‚àà‚Üí‚äë y)

‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë : ‚àÄ{u v : Value}
    ‚Üí u ‚äÜ v
      -----
    ‚Üí u ‚äë v
‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë {‚ä•} s with s {‚ä•} refl
... | x = ‚äë-bot
‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë {u ‚Ü¶ u‚Ä≤} s with s {u ‚Ü¶ u‚Ä≤} refl
... | x = ‚àà‚Üí‚äë x
‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë {u ‚äî u‚Ä≤} s = ‚äë-conj-L (‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë (Œª z ‚Üí s (inj‚ÇÅ z))) (‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë (Œª z ‚Üí s (inj‚ÇÇ z)))

We shall also need some inversion principles for value inclusion. If the union of u and v is included in w, then of course both u and v are each included in w.

‚äî‚äÜ-inv : ‚àÄ{u v w : Value}
       ‚Üí (u ‚äî v) ‚äÜ w
         ---------------
       ‚Üí u ‚äÜ w  √ó  v ‚äÜ w
‚äî‚äÜ-inv uvw = ‚ü® (Œª x ‚Üí uvw (inj‚ÇÅ x)) , (Œª x ‚Üí uvw (inj‚ÇÇ x)) ‚ü©

In our value representation, the function value v ‚Ü¶ w is both an element and also a singleton set. So if v ‚Ü¶ w is a subset of u, then v ‚Ü¶ w must be a member of u.

‚Ü¶‚äÜ‚Üí‚àà : ‚àÄ{v w u : Value}
     ‚Üí v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äÜ u
       ---------
     ‚Üí v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u
‚Ü¶‚äÜ‚Üí‚àà incl = incl refl

Function values

To identify collections of functions, we define the following two predicates. We write Fun u if u is a function value, that is, if u ‚â° v ‚Ü¶ w for some values v and w. We write all-funs v if all the elements of v are functions.

data Fun : Value ‚Üí Set where
  fun : ‚àÄ{u v w} ‚Üí u ‚â° (v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚Üí Fun u

all-funs : Value ‚Üí Set
all-funs v = ‚àÄ{u} ‚Üí u ‚àà v ‚Üí Fun u

The value ‚ä• is not a function.

¬¨Fun‚ä• : ¬¨ (Fun ‚ä•)
¬¨Fun‚ä• (fun ())

In our values-as-sets representation, our sets always include at least one element. Thus, if all the elements are functions, there is at least one that is a function.

all-funs‚àà : ‚àÄ{u}
      ‚Üí all-funs u
      ‚Üí Œ£[ v ‚àà Value ] Œ£[ w ‚àà Value ] v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u
all-funs‚àà {‚ä•} f with f {‚ä•} refl
... | fun ()
all-funs‚àà {v ‚Ü¶ w} f = ‚ü® v , ‚ü® w , refl ‚ü© ‚ü©
all-funs‚àà {u ‚äî u‚Ä≤} f
    with all-funs‚àà Œª z ‚Üí f (inj‚ÇÅ z)
... | ‚ü® v , ‚ü® w , m ‚ü© ‚ü© = ‚ü® v , ‚ü® w , (inj‚ÇÅ m) ‚ü© ‚ü©

Domains and codomains

Returning to our goal, the inversion principle for less-than a function, we want to show that v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äë u implies that u includes a set of function values such that the join of their domains is less than v and the join of their codomains is greater than w.

To this end we define the following dom and cod functions. Given some value u (that represents a set of entries), dom u returns the join of their domains and cod u returns the join of their codomains.

dom : (u : Value) ‚Üí Value
dom ‚ä•  = ‚ä•
dom (v ‚Ü¶ w) = v
dom (u ‚äî u‚Ä≤) = dom u ‚äî dom u‚Ä≤

cod : (u : Value) ‚Üí Value
cod ‚ä•  = ‚ä•
cod (v ‚Ü¶ w) = w
cod (u ‚äî u‚Ä≤) = cod u ‚äî cod u‚Ä≤

We need just one property each for dom and cod. Given a collection of functions represented by value u, and an entry v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u, we know that v is included in the domain of v.

‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom : ‚àÄ{u v w : Value}
          ‚Üí all-funs u  ‚Üí  (v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚àà u
            ----------------------
          ‚Üí v ‚äÜ dom u
‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom {‚ä•} fg () u‚ààv
‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom {v ‚Ü¶ w} fg refl u‚ààv = u‚ààv
‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom {u ‚äî u‚Ä≤} fg (inj‚ÇÅ v‚Ü¶w‚ààu) u‚ààv =
   let ih = ‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom (Œª z ‚Üí fg (inj‚ÇÅ z)) v‚Ü¶w‚ààu in
   inj‚ÇÅ (ih u‚ààv)
‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom {u ‚äî u‚Ä≤} fg (inj‚ÇÇ v‚Ü¶w‚ààu‚Ä≤) u‚ààv =
   let ih = ‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom (Œª z ‚Üí fg (inj‚ÇÇ z)) v‚Ü¶w‚ààu‚Ä≤ in
   inj‚ÇÇ (ih u‚ààv)

Regarding cod, suppose we have a collection of functions represented by u, but all of them are just copies of v ‚Ü¶ w. Then the cod u is included in w.

‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ : ‚àÄ{u v w : Value}
        ‚Üí u ‚äÜ v ‚Ü¶ w
          ---------
        ‚Üí cod u ‚äÜ w
‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ {‚ä•} s refl with s {‚ä•} refl
... | ()
‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ {C ‚Ü¶ C‚Ä≤} s m with s {C ‚Ü¶ C‚Ä≤} refl
... | refl = m
‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ {u ‚äî u‚Ä≤} s (inj‚ÇÅ x) = ‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ (Œª {C} z ‚Üí s (inj‚ÇÅ z)) x
‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ {u ‚äî u‚Ä≤} s (inj‚ÇÇ y) = ‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ (Œª {C} z ‚Üí s (inj‚ÇÇ z)) y

With the dom and cod functions in hand, we can make precise the conclusion of the inversion principle for functions, which we package into the following predicate named factor. We say that v ‚Ü¶ w factors u into u‚Ä≤ if u‚Ä≤ is a included in u, if u‚Ä≤ contains only functions, its domain is less than v, and its codomain is greater than w.

factor : (u : Value) ‚Üí (u‚Ä≤ : Value) ‚Üí (v : Value) ‚Üí (w : Value) ‚Üí Set
factor u u‚Ä≤ v w = all-funs u‚Ä≤ √ó u‚Ä≤ ‚äÜ u √ó dom u‚Ä≤ ‚äë v √ó w ‚äë cod u‚Ä≤

We prove the inversion principle for functions by induction on the derivation of the less-than relation. To make the induction hypothesis stronger, we broaden the premise to u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ (instead of v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äë u), and strengthen the conclusion to say that for every function value v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ, we have that v ‚Ü¶ w factors u‚ÇÇ into some value u‚ÇÉ.

Inversion of less-than for functions, the case for ‚äë-trans

The crux of the proof is the case for ‚äë-trans.

u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u   u ‚äë u‚ÇÇ
--------------- (‚äë-trans)
    u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ

By the induction hypothesis for u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u, we know that v ‚Ü¶ w factors u into u‚Ä≤, for some value u‚Ä≤, so we have all-funs u‚Ä≤ and u‚Ä≤ ‚äÜ u. By the induction hypothesis for u ‚äë u‚ÇÇ, we know that for any v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ ‚àà u, v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ factors u‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÉ. With these facts in hand, we proceed by induction on u‚Ä≤ to prove that (dom u‚Ä≤) ‚Ü¶ (cod u‚Ä≤) factors u‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÉ. We discuss each case of the proof in the text below.

sub-inv-trans : ‚àÄ{u‚Ä≤ u‚ÇÇ u : Value}
    ‚Üí all-funs u‚Ä≤  ‚Üí  u‚Ä≤ ‚äÜ u
    ‚Üí (‚àÄ{v‚Ä≤ w‚Ä≤} ‚Üí v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ ‚àà u ‚Üí Œ£[ u‚ÇÉ ‚àà Value ] factor u‚ÇÇ u‚ÇÉ v‚Ä≤ w‚Ä≤)
      ---------------------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí Œ£[ u‚ÇÉ ‚àà Value ] factor u‚ÇÇ u‚ÇÉ (dom u‚Ä≤) (cod u‚Ä≤)
sub-inv-trans {‚ä•} {u‚ÇÇ} {u} fu‚Ä≤ u‚Ä≤‚äÜu IH =
   ‚ä•-elim (contradiction (fu‚Ä≤ refl) ¬¨Fun‚ä•)
sub-inv-trans {u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤} {u‚ÇÇ} {u} fg u‚Ä≤‚äÜu IH = IH (‚Ü¶‚äÜ‚Üí‚àà u‚Ä≤‚äÜu)
sub-inv-trans {u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤} {u‚ÇÇ} {u} fg u‚Ä≤‚äÜu IH
    with ‚äî‚äÜ-inv u‚Ä≤‚äÜu
... | ‚ü® u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚äÜu , u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤‚äÜu ‚ü©
    with sub-inv-trans {u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤} {u‚ÇÇ} {u} (Œª {v‚Ä≤} z ‚Üí fg (inj‚ÇÅ z)) u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚äÜu IH
       | sub-inv-trans {u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤} {u‚ÇÇ} {u} (Œª {v‚Ä≤} z ‚Üí fg (inj‚ÇÇ z)) u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤‚äÜu IH
... | ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® fu21' , ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® du‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äëdu‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ , cu‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚äëcu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
    | ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® fu22' , ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® du‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äëdu‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ , cu‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚äëcu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© =
      ‚ü® (u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ) , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ , ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤‚äÜu‚ÇÇ ,
      ‚ü® ‚äî‚äë‚äî du‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äëdu‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ du‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äëdu‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ,
        ‚äî‚äë‚äî cu‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚äëcu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ cu‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚äëcu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
    where fu‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ : {v‚Ä≤ : Value} ‚Üí v‚Ä≤ ‚àà u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äé v‚Ä≤ ‚àà u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ ‚Üí Fun v‚Ä≤
          fu‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ {v‚Ä≤} (inj‚ÇÅ x) = fu21' x
          fu‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ {v‚Ä≤} (inj‚ÇÇ y) = fu22' y
          u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤‚äÜu‚ÇÇ : {C : Value} ‚Üí C ‚àà u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äé C ‚àà u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ ‚Üí C ‚àà u‚ÇÇ
          u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤‚äÜu‚ÇÇ {C} (inj‚ÇÅ x) = u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ x
          u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤‚äÜu‚ÇÇ {C} (inj‚ÇÇ y) = u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ y

  • Suppose u‚Ä≤ ‚â° ‚ä•. Then we have a contradiction because it is not the case that Fun ‚ä•.

  • Suppose u‚Ä≤ ‚â° u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤. Then u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ‚àà u and we can apply the premise (the induction hypothesis from u ‚äë u‚ÇÇ) to obtain that u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ factors of u‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤. This case is complete because dom u‚Ä≤ ‚â° u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ and cod u‚Ä≤ ‚â° u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤.

  • Suppose u‚Ä≤ ‚â° u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤. Then we have u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚äÜ u and u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ ‚äÜ u. We also have all-funs u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ and all-funs u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤, so we can apply the induction hypothesis for both u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ and u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤. So there exists values u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ and u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ such that (dom u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤) ‚Ü¶ (cod u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤) factors u into u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ and (dom u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤) ‚Ü¶ (cod u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤) factors u into u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ. We will show that (dom u) ‚Ü¶ (cod u) factors u into u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ. So we need to show that

      dom (u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ) ‚äë dom (u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤)
  cod (u‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤) ‚äë cod (u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ)

    But those both follow directly from the factoring of u into u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ and u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ, using the monotonicity of ‚äî with respect to ‚äë.

Inversion of less-than for functions

We come to the proof of the main lemma concerning the inversion of less-than for functions. We show that if u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ, then for any v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ, we can factor u‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÉ according to v ‚Ü¶ w. We proceed by induction on the derivation of u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ, and describe each case in the text after the Agda proof.

sub-inv : ‚àÄ{u‚ÇÅ u‚ÇÇ : Value}
        ‚Üí u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ
        ‚Üí ‚àÄ{v w} ‚Üí v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ
          -------------------------------------
        ‚Üí Œ£[ u‚ÇÉ ‚àà Value ] factor u‚ÇÇ u‚ÇÉ v w
sub-inv {‚ä•} {u‚ÇÇ} ‚äë-bot {v} {w} ()
sub-inv {u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ} {u‚ÇÇ} (‚äë-conj-L lt1 lt2) {v} {w} (inj‚ÇÅ x) = sub-inv lt1 x
sub-inv {u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ} {u‚ÇÇ} (‚äë-conj-L lt1 lt2) {v} {w} (inj‚ÇÇ y) = sub-inv lt2 y
sub-inv {u‚ÇÅ} {u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ} (‚äë-conj-R1 lt) {v} {w} m
    with sub-inv lt m
... | ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® domu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äëv , w‚äëcodu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© =
      ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® (Œª {w} z ‚Üí inj‚ÇÅ (u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ z)) ,
                                   ‚ü® domu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ‚äëv , w‚äëcodu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
sub-inv {u‚ÇÅ} {u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ} (‚äë-conj-R2 lt) {v} {w} m
    with sub-inv lt m
... | ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® domu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äëv , w‚äëcodu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© =
      ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® (Œª {C} z ‚Üí inj‚ÇÇ (u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ z)) ,
                                   ‚ü® domu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ‚äëv , w‚äëcodu‚ÇÉ‚ÇÇ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
sub-inv {u‚ÇÅ} {u‚ÇÇ} (‚äë-trans{v = u} u‚ÇÅ‚äëu u‚äëu‚ÇÇ) {v} {w} v‚Ü¶w‚ààu‚ÇÅ
    with sub-inv u‚ÇÅ‚äëu v‚Ü¶w‚ààu‚ÇÅ
... | ‚ü® u‚Ä≤ , ‚ü® fu‚Ä≤ , ‚ü® u‚Ä≤‚äÜu , ‚ü® domu‚Ä≤‚äëv , w‚äëcodu‚Ä≤ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
    with sub-inv-trans {u‚Ä≤} fu‚Ä≤ u‚Ä≤‚äÜu (sub-inv u‚äëu‚ÇÇ)
... | ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÉ , ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® domu‚ÇÉ‚äëdomu‚Ä≤ , codu‚Ä≤‚äëcodu‚ÇÉ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© =
      ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ , ‚ü® fu‚ÇÉ , ‚ü® u‚ÇÉ‚äÜu‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® ‚äë-trans domu‚ÇÉ‚äëdomu‚Ä≤ domu‚Ä≤‚äëv ,
                                    ‚äë-trans w‚äëcodu‚Ä≤ codu‚Ä≤‚äëcodu‚ÇÉ ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
sub-inv {u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ} {u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ} (‚äë-fun lt1 lt2) refl =
    ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® (Œª {w} ‚Üí fun) , ‚ü® (Œª {C} z ‚Üí z) , ‚ü® lt1 , lt2 ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
sub-inv {u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ)} {u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ} ‚äë-dist
    {.u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ} {.(u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ)} refl =
    ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ , ‚ü® f , ‚ü® g , ‚ü® ‚äë-conj-L ‚äë-refl ‚äë-refl , ‚äë-refl ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
  where f : all-funs (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ)
        f (inj‚ÇÅ x) = fun x
        f (inj‚ÇÇ y) = fun y
        g : (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ) ‚äÜ (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ)
        g (inj‚ÇÅ x) = inj‚ÇÅ x
        g (inj‚ÇÇ y) = inj‚ÇÇ y

Let v and w be arbitrary values.

  • Case ‚äë-bot. So u‚ÇÅ ‚â° ‚ä•. We have v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà ‚ä•, but that is impossible.

  • Case ‚äë-conj-L.

      u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ   u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ
  -------------------
  u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ

    Given that v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ, there are two subcases to consider.

    • Subcase v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ. We conclude by the induction hypothesis for u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ.

    • Subcase v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ. We conclude by the induction hypothesis for u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ.

  • Case ‚äë-conj-R1.

      u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ
  --------------
  u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ

    Given that v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ, the induction hypothesis for u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ gives us that v ‚Ü¶ w factors u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ into u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ for some u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ. To show that v ‚Ü¶ w also factors u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ, we just need to show that u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äÜ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ, but that follows directly from u‚ÇÉ‚ÇÅ ‚äÜ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ.

  • Case ‚äë-conj-R2. This case follows by reasoning similar to the case for ‚äë-conj-R1.

  • Case ‚äë-trans.

      u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u   u ‚äë u‚ÇÇ
  ---------------
      u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ

    By the induction hypothesis for u‚ÇÅ ‚äë u, we know that v ‚Ü¶ w factors u into u‚Ä≤, for some value u‚Ä≤, so we have all-funs u‚Ä≤ and u‚Ä≤ ‚äÜ u. By the induction hypothesis for u ‚äë u‚ÇÇ, we know that for any v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ ‚àà u, v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ factors u‚ÇÇ. Now we apply the lemma sub-inv-trans, which gives us some u‚ÇÉ such that (dom u‚Ä≤) ‚Ü¶ (cod u‚Ä≤) factors u‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÉ. We show that v ‚Ü¶ w also factors u‚ÇÇ into u‚ÇÉ. From dom u‚ÇÉ ‚äë dom u‚Ä≤ and dom u‚Ä≤ ‚äë v, we have dom u‚ÇÉ ‚äë v. From w ‚äë cod u‚Ä≤ and cod u‚Ä≤ ‚äë cod u‚ÇÉ, we have w ‚äë cod u‚ÇÉ, and this case is complete.

  • Case ‚äë-fun.

      u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ  u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ
  ---------------------
  u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ

    Given that v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ, we have v ‚â° u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ and w ‚â° u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ. We show that u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ factors u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ into itself. We need to show that dom (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ) ‚äë u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ and u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë cod (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ), but that is equivalent to our premises u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ and u‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ.

  • Case ‚äë-dist.

      ---------------------------------------------
  u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ) ‚äë (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ) ‚äî (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ)

    Given that v ‚Ü¶ w ‚àà u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ), we have v ‚â° u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ and w ‚â° u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ. We show that u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ) factors (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ) ‚äî (u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚Ü¶ u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ) into itself. We have u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ, and also u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ ‚äë u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ ‚äî u‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ, so the proof is complete.

We conclude this section with two corollaries of the sub-inv lemma. First, we have the following property that is convenient to use in later proofs. We specialize the premise to just v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äë u‚ÇÅ and we modify the conclusion to say that for every v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤ ‚àà u‚ÇÇ, we have v‚Ä≤ ‚äë v.

sub-inv-fun : ‚àÄ{v w u‚ÇÅ : Value}
    ‚Üí (v ‚Ü¶ w) ‚äë u‚ÇÅ
      -----------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí Œ£[ u‚ÇÇ ‚àà Value ] all-funs u‚ÇÇ √ó u‚ÇÇ ‚äÜ u‚ÇÅ
        √ó (‚àÄ{v‚Ä≤ w‚Ä≤} ‚Üí (v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤) ‚àà u‚ÇÇ ‚Üí v‚Ä≤ ‚äë v) √ó w ‚äë cod u‚ÇÇ
sub-inv-fun{v}{w}{u‚ÇÅ} abc
    with sub-inv abc {v}{w} refl
... | ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® f , ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ‚äÜu‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® db , cc ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© =
      ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ , ‚ü® f , ‚ü® u‚ÇÇ‚äÜu‚ÇÅ , ‚ü® G , cc ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
   where G : ‚àÄ{D E} ‚Üí (D ‚Ü¶ E) ‚àà u‚ÇÇ ‚Üí D ‚äë v
         G{D}{E} m = ‚äë-trans (‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë (‚Ü¶‚àà‚Üí‚äÜdom f m)) db

The second corollary is the inversion rule that one would expect for less-than with functions on the left and right-hand sides.

‚Ü¶‚äë‚Ü¶-inv : ‚àÄ{v w v‚Ä≤ w‚Ä≤}
        ‚Üí v ‚Ü¶ w ‚äë v‚Ä≤ ‚Ü¶ w‚Ä≤
          -----------------
        ‚Üí v‚Ä≤ ‚äë v √ó w ‚äë w‚Ä≤
‚Ü¶‚äë‚Ü¶-inv{v}{w}{v‚Ä≤}{w‚Ä≤} lt
    with sub-inv-fun lt
... | ‚ü® Œì , ‚ü® f , ‚ü® Œì‚äÜv34 , ‚ü® lt1 , lt2 ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü© ‚ü©
    with all-funs‚àà f
... | ‚ü® u , ‚ü® u‚Ä≤ , u‚Ü¶u‚Ä≤‚ààŒì ‚ü© ‚ü©
    with Œì‚äÜv34 u‚Ü¶u‚Ä≤‚ààŒì
... | refl =
  let codŒì‚äÜw‚Ä≤ = ‚äÜ‚Ü¶‚Üícod‚äÜ Œì‚äÜv34 in
  ‚ü® lt1 u‚Ü¶u‚Ä≤‚ààŒì , ‚äë-trans lt2 (‚äÜ‚Üí‚äë codŒì‚äÜw‚Ä≤) ‚ü©

Notes

The denotational semantics presented in this chapter is an example of a filter model (Barendregt, Coppo, Dezani-Ciancaglini, 1983). Filter models use type systems with intersection types to precisely characterize runtime behavior (Coppo, Dezani-Ciancaglini, and Salle, 1979). The notation that we use in this chapter is not that of type systems and intersection types, but the Value data type is isomorphic to types (‚Ü¶ is ‚Üí, ‚äî is ‚àß, ‚ä• is ‚ä§), the ‚äë relation is the inverse of subtyping <:, and the evaluation relation œÅ ‚ä¢ M ‚Üì v is isomorphic to a type system. Write Œì instead of œÅ, A instead of v, and replace ‚Üì with : and one has a typing judgement Œì ‚ä¢ M : A. By varying the definition of subtyping and using different choices of type atoms, intersection type systems provide semantics for many different untyped Œª calculi, from full beta to the lazy and call-by-value calculi (Alessi, Barbanera, and Dezani-Ciancaglini, 2006) (Rocca and Paolini, 2004). The denotational semantics in this chapter corresponds to the BCD system (Barendregt, Coppo, Dezani-Ciancaglini, 1983). Part 3 of the book Lambda Calculus with Types describes a framework for intersection type systems that enables results similar to the ones in this chapter, but for the entire family of intersection type systems (Barendregt, Dekkers, and Statman, 2013).

The two ideas of using finite tables to represent functions and of relaxing table lookup to enable self application first appeared in a technical report by Gordon Plotkin (1972) and are later described in an article in Theoretical Computer Science (Plotkin 1993). In that work, the inductive definition of Value is a bit different than the one we use:

Value = C + ‚Ñòf(Value) √ó ‚Ñòf(Value)

where C is a set of constants and ‚Ñòf means finite powerset. The pairs in ‚Ñòf(Value) √ó ‚Ñòf(Value) represent input-output mappings, just as in this chapter. The finite powersets are used to enable a function table to appear in the input and in the output. These differences amount to changing where the recursion appears in the definition of Value. Plotkin‚Äôs model is an example of a graph model of the untyped lambda calculus (Barendregt, 1984). In a graph model, the semantics is presented as a function from programs and environments to (possibly infinite) sets of values. The semantics in this chapter is instead defined as a relation, but set-valued functions are isomorphic to relations. Indeed, we present the semantics as a function in the next chapter and prove that it is equivalent to the relational version.

Dana Scott‚Äôs ‚Ñò(œâ) (1976) and Engeler‚Äôs B(A) (1981) are two more examples of graph models. Both use the following inductive definition of Value.

Value = C + ‚Ñòf(Value) √ó Value

The use of Value instead of ‚Ñòf(Value) in the output does not restrict expressiveness compared to Plotkin‚Äôs model because the semantics use sets of values and a pair of sets (V, V‚Ä≤) can be represented as a set of pairs { (V, v‚Ä≤) | v‚Ä≤ ‚àà V‚Ä≤ }. In Scott‚Äôs ‚Ñò(œâ), the above values are mapped to and from the natural numbers using a kind of Godel encoding.
